questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency room because of a 4-day history of progressively worsening pain and swelling on the right side of his face. The patient was diagnosed with multiple myeloma 8 months ago and is currently undergoing treatment. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows erythema and swelling over the right cheek and mandible. An orofacial fistula is present. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug that is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of angiogenesis is the mechanism of action of bevacizumab, a drug that is typically used to treat solid tumors (e.g., colorectal cancer, renal cell carcinoma) and wet age-related macular degeneration. Significant adverse effects include hemorrhage, blood clots, and impaired wound healing. Bevacizumab is not used to treat multiple myeloma and is not associated with osteonecrosis of the jaw.

B) INCORRECT:

Cross-linking DNA at guanine is the mechanism of action of cyclophosphamide, a drug regularly used in the treatment of multiple myeloma. Major adverse effects include hemorrhagic cystitis and SIADH. Cyclophosphamide is not associated with osteonecrosis of the jaw.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of proteasome activity is the mechanism of action of bortezomib, a cytostatic drug that arrests cell growth at the G2-M phase and causes apoptosis. It is first-line treatment for multiple myeloma and is associated with polyneuropathy and reactivation of herpes zoster. It does not cause osteonecrosis of the jaw.

D) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of PTH receptors is the mechanism of action of teriparatide. Teriparatide can enhance bone resorption by stimulating osteoclastic activity, but the net increase in bone formation through upregulation of osteoblastic activity predominates. Teriparatide is associated with the development of osteosarcoma and may cause transient hypercalcemia, but it does not cause osteonecrosis of the jaw.

E) CORRECT:

Binding to hydroxyapatite on the surface of bone tissue is the mechanism of action of bisphosphonates, a group of drugs used in the treatment of multiple myeloma. Bisphosphonates are pyrophosphate analogs that decrease bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity. The pathophysiology of bisphosphonate-induced osteonecrosis of the jaw is not yet fully understood. Trauma (e.g., during dental procedures) may act as a trigger. Other important adverse effects of bisphosphonate therapy include hypocalcemia, renal impairment, and esophagitis.
questions.hint: This patient's painful swelling, erythema, and orofacial fistula indicate osteonecrosis of the jaw.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of left wrist pain and swelling that began after she fell from a seated position. Menopause occurred 15 years ago. Her serum parathyroid hormone level is within normal limits. An x-ray of the left wrist shows a nondisplaced fracture of the distal radial metaphysis and decreased bone mineral density. The patient would likely benefit from an agent with a structure analogous to which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inositol is a supplement given to women in the treatment of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Studies have shown that inositol supplementation can increase insulin sensitivity and indirectly improve bone density through the management of metabolic syndrome. However, inositol is not structurally analogous to bisphosphonates.

B) INCORRECT:

Proteoglycans (PGs), such as keratan sulfate, are macromolecules consisting of a protein core with 50 to 100 unbranched glycosaminoglycans. Keratan sulfate forms part of the bone extracellular matrix and functions to support and organize bone tissue. However, PGs are not structurally analogous to bisphosphonates.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyapatite crystals are the inorganic component of the bone matrix and are sites for bisphosphonate binding. Hydroxyapatite crystals coated with bisphosphonates are absorbed by osteoclasts, whereby the bisphosphonates impair metabolism in the cells, inducing apoptosis and decreasing bone resorption. However, hydroxyapatite crystals are not structurally analogous to bisphosphonates.

D) INCORRECT:

Nitric oxide (NO) is the metabolite of several anti-anginal and antihypertensive drugs and acts as a vasodilator in the cardiovascular system. While endogenous NO acts as a local hormonal regulator of bone homeostasis, the effects of orally-taken NO precursors (e.g., nitroglycerin) on bone metabolism have not been established. NO compounds are not structurally analogous to bisphosphonates.

E) CORRECT:

Inorganic pyrophosphates are compounds formed by the linkage of two phosphate ions and are found endogenously in all cells. Bisphosphonates are structurally analogous to inorganic pyrophosphates and attach to binding sites on hydroxyapatite, where pyrophosphate would normally bind. When these bisphosphonate-coated hydroxyapatite crystals are taken up by osteoclasts during bone resorption, the bisphosphonate interferes with osteoclast functions, thereby reducing bone resorption. Bisphosphonates also reduce osteoclast activity by inducing apoptosis.
questions.hint: A postmenopausal woman presenting with a fracture on a background of decreased bone mineral density suggests osteoporosis. Bisphosphonates are indicated.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of headaches and back pain. Examination shows mild sensorineural hearing loss. Serum concentration of alkaline phosphatase is increased. An x-ray of the skull is shown. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient is a drug that has which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of tubulin polymerization occurs after administration of vinca alkaloids or colchicine. Vinca drugs are potent antineoplastic agents and colchicine is used in gout. Neither are indicated in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of nuclear factor-κB is the mechanism of denosumab and glucocorticoids. Denosumab is most often used in the treatment of osteoporosis, whereas glucocorticoids can be used as an intraarticular injection to treat osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis and vertebral compression fractures due to osteoporosis can cause back pain but this patient's imaging findings, increased ALP, and new onset hearing loss are consistent with neither osteoporosis nor osteoarthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Formation of DNA strand breaks is the mechanism by which various antineoplastic drugs, such as bleomycin, cladribine, and doxorubicin, function. Chemotherapy does not have a role in treating Paget disease of bone.

D) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of osteoblasts is the goal of therapy with teriparatide in patients with osteoporosis. This drug is a parathyroid hormone (PTH) analog but has an apparently paradoxical effect when given in a pulsatile fashion compared to the continuous release of PTH under physiologic conditions. Advanced osteoporosis can cause back pain due to compression fractures but osteoporosis would not cause headaches, sensorineural hearing loss, increased ALP, or the imaging findings seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of proteasomes is the mechanism of bortezomib, which is most commonly used in treating multiple myeloma. The patient described here presents with chronic back pain, headache, and osteolytic lesions, all of which could be consistent with multiple myeloma. However, this patient's skull imaging with diffuse sclerosis and calavarial thickening is not consistent with this diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

The mainstay of treatment for Paget disease of bone is bisphosphonate therapy, which functions by inducing apoptosis of osteoclasts. These drugs bind directly to the bone surface and are eventually taken up by osteoclasts during bone resorption. Once within a cell, they interfere with osteoclast survival, leading to apoptosis and reduced bone resorption.
questions.hint: The combination of hearing loss, headaches, and an elevated alkaline phosphatase concentration is concerning for a diagnosis of Paget disease of bone. The x-ray showing characteristic deformities of bone including thickening of the calvaria, sclerotic and osteolytic lesions, and osteoblastic lesions confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of hematemesis and progressive heartburn over the past 5 days. Ten days ago, he was started on a medication to treat a condition that causes hearing difficulties and pain in the lower extremities. He has no other history of serious illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bowing of the tibias. Upper endoscopy shows inflammation of the mucosa and a 1-cm punched-out ulcer in the distal esophagus. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium citrate may be given as a supplement to prevent hypocalcemia and secondary hyperparathyroidism in Paget disease of bone. However, calcium citrate is not associated with esophagitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Denosumab inhibits osteoclasts and reduces bone resorption. It is administered as a subcutaneous injection to treat osteoporosis. Denosumab is not currently recommended for use in Paget disease of bone, and it is not associated with esophagitis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's drug-induced esophagitis is most likely due to oral bisphosphonate therapy (e.g., risedronate). Bisphosphonates, which inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, are the first-line treatment for Paget disease of the bone. Oral bisphosphonates may cause erosive esophagitis and esophageal cancer, especially in patients who do not maintain an upright posture for 30–60 minutes after ingestion. Other side effects of bisphosphonates (both IV and oral) include aseptic osteonecrosis of the jaw, atypical femoral fractures, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia. IV bisphosphonates (e.g., zoledronate) may cause an acute-phase reaction with flu-like symptoms 24–72 hours after administration.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcitonin reduces bone resorption and disease activity in Paget disease of bone. Because it is less effective than the first-line treatment, it is only used if the first-line therapy is poorly tolerated. Calcitonin is administered as a subcutaneous injection and does not cause esophagitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisolone can cause drug-induced esophagitis, peptic ulcers, and gastrointestinal hemorrhage. However, prednisolone should be avoided in patients with Paget disease of bone because prolonged use may lead to osteoporosis and further increase the risk of fragility fractures. Therefore, it is unlikely that this patient was treated with prednisolone.

F) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen can cause drug-induced esophagitis and may be used as an adjunct to help relieve bone pain in Paget disease of bone. However, acetaminophen is not the first-line therapy for this condition, and the preferred treatment option for this patient is associated with a higher risk of esophagitis than acetaminophen.
questions.hint: This patient's hearing difficulties, bone pain, and tibial bowing raise suspicion for Paget disease of bone. Heartburn, hematemesis, and an esophageal ulcer occurring after treatment was initiated indicate drug-induced esophagitis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive pain and swelling of her right jaw over the past 8 weeks. She says that the symptoms started slowly and the pain varies in intensity. She was diagnosed with osteoporosis 15 months ago after she developed a vertebral compression fracture. Her T-score at the time of diagnosis was -3.5 and she was prescribed oral alendronate to be taken weekly. She smokes 5 cigarettes daily and drinks one beer every two to three days. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is pain and tenderness upon palpation of the right temporomandibular joint. Intraoral examination shows gingival erythema and swelling around the right lower molars without purulent discharge. A part of the alveolar bone of the mandible in the same area is exposed. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's orofacial disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smoking cessation should be recommended in patients receiving bisphosphonates because smoking is a possible risk factor for MRONJ. However, other risk factors are more strongly associated with the development of MRONJ, and there is another more effective measure for preventing this patient's adverse effect.

B) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotic therapy can be used as a preventive measure in patients receiving bisphosphonate therapy prior to oral surgery and to prevent recurrence in already established MRONJ. In addition, antibiotic therapy is used in the treatment of MRONJ to promote healing. However, preventive antibiotic therapy is not generally indicated in patients receiving bisphosphonate therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Preprandial medication intake (preferably in the morning 60 minutes before breakfast) is recommended in oral bisphosphonate therapy to enhance absorption. However, this strategy is not effective in preventing side effects such as MRONJ. The risk of other complications of oral bisphosphonate therapy, such as esophageal inflammation and reflux, can be minimized by swallowing bisphosphonates with a sufficient amount of water and maintaining an upright position for 30 minutes after medication intake.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium supplementation is commonly provided during bisphosphonate therapy to reduce the risk of hypocalcemia. However, calcium supplementation has not been shown to reduce the risk of MRONJ. Since calcium forms complexes with bisphosphonates, it can reduce absorption, and neither supplements nor food should be taken within 60 minutes of oral bisphosphonate administration.

E) CORRECT:

MRONJ is a rare but serious side effect of bisphosphonate therapy and is most commonly seen in high-dose IV administration in cancer patients, but it can also occur with oral administration (e.g., for osteoporosis). The underlying pathophysiology is not yet fully understood, but it is assumed that bisphosphonate's antiangiogenic effects in combination with the jaw's specific characteristics (e.g., high metabolism) play a role. Invasive dental procedures are a major risk factor for the development of MRONJ. Therefore, patient education and preventive measures, such as a comprehensive dental examination in conjunction with treatment of preexisting dental conditions (e.g., extraction of unrestorable teeth), are strongly encouraged prior to initiation of antiresorptive therapy. After the initiation of therapy, a daily oral care plan should be encouraged, entailing instructions on oral hygiene (e.g., daily oral rinsing, brushing, and flossing) as well as regular check-ups and cleanings.

Treatment of established MRONJ is mainly supportive and includes improved oral hygiene, antibiotic treatment, and limited debridement. Surgery should be avoided if possible.
questions.hint: Pain, erythema, swelling of the jaw, and an area of exposed bone in a patient who has received long-term therapy with alendronate indicate medication-related osteonecrosis of the jaw (MRONJ), a complication of antiresorptive drugs (e.g., bisphosphonates, RANKL inhibitors) and antiangiogenic drugs (e.g., VEGF inhibitors).

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman with a history of hypothyroidism and osteoporosis presents with severe right groin and thigh pain after tripping and falling over a crack in the sidewalk. She had noted right thigh discomfort for several months preceding the fall. For the past 10 years, she has been taking levothyroxine 75 μg daily, vitamin D3 25 μg (1000 IU) daily, and alendronate 70 mg weekly. On bone mineral density testing one year ago, T scores for her right total hip and femoral neck were –3.0 and –2.7, respectively. At a recent office visit, her weight was 63.5 kg, and her BMI was 24.
Physical examination reveals tenderness around the right thigh and hip — and pain when the right hip is moved.
A radiograph of the right hip and femur is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's fracture?

choices.text: Adverse effect of prolonged bisphosphonate use

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteomalacia generally causes thinning of the cortex and pseudofractures, not thickening (as seen with atypical bisphosphonate-associated fractures). Patients with osteomalacia may present with pseudofractures, which are narrow radiolucent lines on the femoral shaft. Vitamin D deficiency is a cause of osteomalacia, but this patient is taking a reasonable dose of supplemental vitamin D.

B) CORRECT:

Prolonged bisphosphonate use (>5–10 years) is associated with the development of atypical fractures, which usually occur with minimal or no trauma and are located below the trochanter or within the femoral shaft; they may be bilateral. Patients may present with prodromal pain, such as groin or thigh pain, before the fracture occurs. Radiologically, these cases are characterized by a transverse, noncomminuted fracture, with cortical hypertrophy and a medial spike. These are termed chalkstick fractures for their radiographic similarity to a broken piece of chalk. Other conditions that can cause chalkstick fractures include Paget’s disease of bone and osteopetrosis.

Key learning point: The typical characteristics of a bisphosphonate-associated atypical fracture include occurrence in the subtrochanteric area or the shaft of the femur, often with minimal trauma.

C) INCORRECT:

Lower-extremity fractures due to osteoporosis usually occur in the femoral neck and femoral head, not in the subtrochanteric or femoral shaft areas. When osteoporosis is associated with thyroid disease, the disorder is generally hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism. At a daily levothyroxine dose of 75 μg, iatrogenic hyperthyroidism is extremely unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

When osteoporosis is associated with thyroid disease, the disorder is generally hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism. At a daily levothyroxine dose of 75 μg, iatrogenic hyperthyroidism is extremely unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

A pathological fracture from a malignancy would probably show involvement of the bone at the fracture site; these fractures are not typically transverse and noncomminuted.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to the infusion center for her first infusion of zoledronic acid. At age 58, she was diagnosed with osteoporosis of the spine and hip after presenting with a wrist fracture and undergoing bone mineral density (BMD) screening. She currently has hypertension, for which she takes lisinopril 10 mg by mouth once daily.
For 10 years, the patient was treated with hormone-replacement therapy involving oral conjugated equine estrogen and medroxyprogesterone, and her BMD stabilized. Four years ago, the estrogen-replacement therapy was stopped because the patient was concerned about potential side effects.
Repeat BMD testing at age 70 revealed worsening of the osteoporosis, with a T score of −3.2 at the spine and −3.6 at the femoral neck. Oral alendronate was started but not continued, because of gastrointestinal side effects.
Laboratory testing reveals an estimated glomerular filtration rate of >60 mL/min/1.73 m2, as well as the following other results:



Patient value
Reference range


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.0
9.0–10.5


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
3.1
3.0–4.5


Albumin (g/dl)
3.8
3.5–5.5


Magnesium (mg/dL)
2.1
1.8–3.0


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
18
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.8
0.6–1.1



25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
12
30–80


Which one of the following approaches is most appropriate for managing this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Recommend ergocalciferol 50,000 units weekly for 8 weeks, and reschedule the infusion
Prescribe prednisone 20 mg daily to be taken for 2 days before and 5 days after the infusion
Prescribe diphenhydramine 50 mg twice daily for 3 days after the infusion
Recommend calcium carbonate 2500 mg (1000 mg of elemental calcium) 3 times daily, for 3 days after the infusion
Prescribe cholecalciferol 400 units daily to be started the day after the infusion

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intravenous bisphosphonates are useful in managing osteoporosis in patients who cannot tolerate oral bisphosphonates or are not responsive to them. Intravenous bisphosphonates are generally safe, and acetaminophen use can prevent their main potential side effect — an acute-phase reaction characterized by arthralgia, headache, myalgia, and fever. Renal failure is an indication for dose adjustment, cessation, or avoidance of intravenous bisphosphonates; hence, a creatinine level should be checked before treatment.

The use of intravenous bisphosphonates in patients with vitamin D deficiency can precipitate severe hypocalcemia. This is due to low calcium absorption from the vitamin D deficiency, compounded by the inability to release calcium from bone because of bisphosphonate-mediated suppression of bone turnover. Hence, calcium and vitamin D levels should be checked before treatment with an intravenous bisphosphonate, and treatment should be deferred until a low vitamin D level has been corrected to a level >20 ng/mL.

Key learning point: In patients with vitamin D deficiency, intravenous bisphosphonates are contraindicated until vitamin D sufficiency has been restored.

B) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is not indicated for patients receiving intravenous bisphosphonates.

C) INCORRECT:

Diphenhydramine is not indicated for patients receiving intravenous bisphosphonates.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium carbonate is unlikely to be absorbed sufficiently in a patient with vitamin D deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Replacement with 400 units of cholecalciferol daily is inadequate to restore vitamin D sufficiency.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents for routine follow-up. Her breast cancer, diagnosed 2 years ago, was treated with lumpectomy and radiation, with no evidence since of metastasis or recurrence. Her chronic obstructive pulmonary disease has been fairly well controlled with the use of fluticasone 250 μg-salmeterol 50 μg (one puff inhaled twice daily); however, exacerbations have required multiple courses of oral glucocorticoids (with tapering of the dose).
Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry, performed 2 years ago, revealed a lumbar spine T score of −2.1 and a femoral neck T score of −2.9. No identifiable secondary cause of osteoporosis was found after a comprehensive evaluation. Oral alendronate 70 mg once weekly was initiated, and the patient reports that she has taken it correctly, having forgotten only a few doses. She has had no adverse effects.
Repeat bone mineral density (BMD) testing, completed at today’s visit, shows a lumbar spine T score of −2.5 and a femoral neck T score of −3.4 (representing a decrease in BMD of 5.2% and 10.8%, respectively).
The patient’s level of C-terminal telopeptide, a marker of bone turnover, is 520 pg/mL (reference range, 104–1008).
Which one of the following treatment decisions is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s osteoporosis?

choices.text: Replace the alendronate with zoledronic acid
Double the weekly dose of alendronate
Continue the alendronate at the current dose

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Raloxifene and calcitonin are less effective than treatment with a bisphosphonate, and neither is recommended as a substitute for an oral bisphosphonate in a patient with declining bone mineral density.

B) CORRECT:

Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate, reduce fracture risk by reducing bone turnover through inhibition of osteoclast activity. Markers of osteoclast activity, such as C-terminal telopeptide (CTX), should therefore be suppressed in patients taking bisphosphonates, and bone mineral density (BMD) is expected to stabilize or improve. In this patient, BMD has continued to decline and her CTX level is not suppressed, indicating a lack of response to alendronate.

An inadequate response to treatment with an oral bisphosphonate should prompt an evaluation for contributing factors such as inadequate treatment adherence, poor gastrointestinal absorption, or insufficient intake of calcium and vitamin D. This patient has no such factors, so it would be appropriate to switch her to an intravenous bisphosphonate, specifically zoledronic acid 5 mg yearly. Treatment with denosumab is also an option for patients who are intolerant of or unresponsive to therapy with a bisphosphonate.

Key learning point: A patient with osteoporosis who continues to lose bone despite therapy with an oral bisphosphonate should be treated with an intravenous bisphosphonate or denosumab.

C) INCORRECT:

Continued treatment with alendronate or another oral bisphosphonate is unlikely to benefit a patient who has declining bone mineral density despite being adherent to treatment, and escalation of the dose has not been shown to be effective or safe.

D) INCORRECT:

Continued treatment with alendronate or another oral bisphosphonate is unlikely to benefit a patient who has declining bone mineral density despite being adherent to treatment, and escalation of the dose has not been shown to be effective or safe.

E) INCORRECT:

Raloxifene and calcitonin are less effective than treatment with a bisphosphonate, and neither is recommended as a substitute for an oral bisphosphonate in a patient with declining bone mineral density.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic with hematemesis and progressively worsening heartburn over the past 5 days. Ten days ago, you started him on a medication to treat a condition associated with hearing difficulties and pain in the lower extremities. He has no other significant medical history. He has a 20-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is bowing of the tibias. Upper endoscopy reveals mucosal inflammation and a 1-cm punched-out ulcer in the distal esophagus. Which one of the following drugs is the most likely cause of his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisolone can cause drug-induced esophagitis, peptic ulcers, and gastrointestinal hemorrhage. However, prednisolone should be avoided in patients with Paget disease of bone because prolonged use may lead to osteoporosis and further increase the risk of fragility fractures. Therefore, it is unlikely that this patient was treated with prednisolone.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen can cause drug-induced esophagitis and may be used as an adjunct to help relieve bone pain in Paget disease of bone. However, acetaminophen is not the first-line therapy for this condition, and the preferred treatment option for this patient is associated with a higher risk of esophagitis than acetaminophen.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcitonin reduces bone resorption and disease activity in Paget disease of bone. Because it is less effective than the first-line treatment, it is only used if the first-line therapy is poorly tolerated. Calcitonin is administered as a subcutaneous injection and does not cause esophagitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Denosumab inhibits osteoclasts and reduces bone resorption. It is administered as a subcutaneous injection to treat osteoporosis. Denosumab is not currently recommended for use in Paget disease of bone, and it is not associated with esophagitis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's drug-induced esophagitis is most likely due to oral bisphosphonate therapy (e.g., risedronate). Bisphosphonates, which inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, are the first-line treatment for Paget disease of the bone. Oral bisphosphonates may cause erosive esophagitis and esophageal cancer, especially in patients who do not maintain an upright posture for 30–60 minutes after ingestion. Other side effects of bisphosphonates (both IV and oral) include aseptic osteonecrosis of the jaw, atypical femoral fractures, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia. IV bisphosphonates (e.g., zoledronate) may cause an acute-phase reaction with flu-like symptoms 24–72 hours after administration.

Key learning point: Oral bisphosphonates, the first-line treatment for Paget disease of bone, can cause drug-induced esophagitis if not taken properly.
questions.hint: This patient's hearing difficulties, bone pain, and tibial bowing raise suspicion for Paget disease of bone. Heartburn, hematemesis, and an esophageal ulcer occurring after treatment was initiated indicate drug-induced esophagitis.
